field_edited_text.value:
Policy:
Expand and improve the City’s
shoreline park system.

"9

#
Policy:
Expand opportunities for the
development of marinas and-safe
recreational boating on the harbor
consistent with the operation of a
working port.

The City is undertaking a number of
projects to use available shoreline for pub-
lic access, recreation and boating. These
projects range in size from small street end
parks for specific communities like Hull
Street in Locust Point to larger city and
regional facilities like Forts Smallwood and
Armistead and the Middle Branch Park
System.

The Middle Branch Park is a major
addition to the City’s park system. Located
on the Patapsco River it touches the South
Baltimore, Westport, Cherry Hill and Brook-
lyn communities. The park combines over
150 acres of completed landfills, existing
City parks and acquisition of derelict shore-
line uses. While initial steps are being taken
now, full development is expected to take
over ten years. The City began in 1978 mak-
Ing improvements to the shoreline, build-
ing new recreational facilities and public
boat launches and encouraging a clean-up
of the shoreline by private owners. When
completed the park will offer residents a
unique recreational resource stretching
from the harbor almost 30 miles up the
Patapsco River State Park System.

The City is working with private devel-
opers on Boston Street and in Fells Point to
develop a continuous public waterfront
walk stretching from the Canton shoreline
to the Inner Harbor. When completed the
public walk will extend over 2 miles con-
necting the Inner Harbor’s many activities
to communities, Fells Point’s historic water-
front, and new residential and recreational
development along Boston Street and in
Canton.

Fort Smallwood, in Anne Arundel
County and Fort Armistead in the Hawkins
Point area of the City will have major
improvements made through the 1980’s.
Both will offer a variety of active recrea-
tion, beaches, walkways, boat launches and
natural areas when completed. Both also
offer the potential for excursion boat access
from the City’s Inner Harbor.

There is considerable demand for
recreational boating and existing facilities
offered by marinas in the harbor. The Inner
Harbor Marina with almost 170 slips has a
waiting list. Reservations for berthing along
the promenade and Piers 4, 5, and 6 are
required in the boating season. Over 1,000
additional slips have been approved in con-
junction with residential development
along the Fells Point/Boston Street
shoreline.

Realizing the tremendous increase in
boating and the potential for conflicts with
commercial shipping the Mayor established
a task force to review applications for mari-
nas, offer suggestions as to control of boat



Baltimore City Marine Police



104
